image.altText: Labor candidate for Dunstan Cressida O'Hanlon.

props.synopsis: While both major parties have stopped short of conceding defeat or claiming victory in SA's Dunstan by-election, the premier says his party is in an "extraordinary position" while the opposition leader admits holding the seat will be "exceptionally difficult".

title.children: Labor in 'extraordinary position' in Dunstan as Liberal leader apologises for result so far

image.altText: Russell Crowe stars in a scene from the movie Robin Hood

props.synopsis: As a heated by-election campaign wrapped up for former South Australian Premier Steven Marshall's former seat, the SA Liberals converged on their scene of defeat at the last state election.

title.children: Robin Hood and the duel for SA's most marginal seat

image.altText: Wes Herring leaning against his ute.

props.synopsis: He didn't know it at the time, but Wes Herring wasn't standing alone on the precipice of breaking point — we explore how he and others are overcoming the mental torments of life on the land.

title.children: Wes once felt he had no choice but to end it all. He's glad he didn't become a statistic

image.altText: A man wearing a Lego police officer costume with a female police officer outside a police station.

props.synopsis: Alex McIntyre wore the first version of his Lego suit in 2013 and has walked 100km for charity in it, but now the 36-year-old has decided to put his life as a giant mini figure behind him.

title.children: Mount Gambier's Human Lego Man is hanging up his big, yellow head for the last time

image.altText: Marilyn adjusts Audra's wedding veil

props.synopsis: Marilyn Rulyancich's baby was snatched from her during Australia's forced adoption era. But she never gave up hope of seeing her again — and now she's telling her remarkable story of subterfuge, detective work and sheer determination.

title.children: When Audra got married, she had no idea her mother she never met was standing right behind her

image.altText: An aerial view of a truck on a highway, driving through arid bushland.

props.synopsis: A South Australian man is charged with manslaughter over the death of a cyclist on a remote stretch of outback Western Australian highway.

title.children: Truck driver charged over outback cyclist's death in Indian Pacific road race

image.altText: A composite image of Jeremy Rockliff and Rebecca White on election night.

props.synopsis: Despite calling an early election to regain majority government, the Tasmanian Liberals have fallen short. But so too has Labor. Here's what will happen next.

title.children: Confused about the Tasmanian election result? You are not alone

image.altText: three men wearing kufis standing in a line with their hands in front of them

props.synopsis: In regional South Australia, minority religions such as Sikhism are growing, while some Christian churches are looking for ways to adapt as congregations shrink.

title.children: As people move from India to regional Australia, temples like these 'feel like home'

image.altText: Composite image showing Andrew Sarakinis aka DJ Sarez leaning on a wooden vineyard post with him DJing at a club.

props.synopsis: With the wine industry in crisis, Andrew Sarakinis is glad his career in music allows him to provide for his family financially and still honour his" blockie" roots.

title.children: Grape grower by day, DJ by night: The 'blockie' who's played the same festivals as The Prodigy

image.altText: A Crows players stands and watches a fan fall to ground as a security officer runs over in the middle of the game.

props.synopsis: Chris Scott and Matthew Nicks raise concerns about the safety of players after the Crows' Ben Keays helped bring to ground a spectator who ran onto Adelaide Oval during the Cats' 19-point win.

title.children: AFL coaches slam 'dangerous' Adelaide Oval pitch invader amid player safety concerns

image.altText: A picture of Hardeep Singh Nijjar and his wife.

props.synopsis: India has denied killing Hardeep Singh Nijjar, but an ABC investigation has found evidence government agencies were searching his family home in Punjab in the weeks before his death.

title.children: His home was raided in India. Weeks later, he was found dead on the other side of the world

image.altText: Julia Baird, who has short brown-blonde hair and is wearing a black wetsuit, looks over the ocean in morning sunlight

props.synopsis: One of the greatest myths is that by just being positive, or cheerful, we can somehow erase our problems.What I'm more interested in is the simpler question of: how do we go on?

title.children: 'Seven times down, eight times up': When life is hard, how do we go on?

image.altText: The outside of a Medibank branch.

props.synopsis: As private health premiums are set to rise, some Australians are making a conscious decision to opt for "self-insurance" rather than "health insurance" to cut down on expenses. Experts warn it's not for everyone.

title.children: With health insurance premiums about to increase, these people decided to 'self-fund' their private healthcare instead

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed and a serious look on his face. The Hard Quiz has been added behind his head

props.synopsis: Oh, you're back? Something to prove after last week's effort? Let's see what you've got.

title.children: Don't be shy now, you think you know it all. Prove it. Let's play … HARD!

image.altText: A woman in a tiara and blue cape in a carriage

props.synopsis: The palace has a difficult job ahead managing the public's insatiable desire for information, respecting Catherine's treatment and privacy, and calming speculation in the digital age, writes Isabella Higgins.

title.children: Kate has asked for a reprieve. Her request will test the palace, the tabloids and her future subjects

image.altText: An older boy in shorts, his mum, a younger boy, his dad and a girl in a uniform walk hand in hand

props.synopsis: The Princess of Wales' cancer revelation helps explain a turbulent few months within the House of Windsor. This is how a chaotic start to 2024 unfolded for the royals.

title.children: From an absence at a family event to a call to the BBC. This is how Kate's diagnosis unfolded

image.altText: Graphic image with Donald Trump appearing above images of Tim Scott, Kristi Noem and Marjorie Taylor Greene.

props.synopsis: A gun-loving grandma, a former Democrat and a MAGA frontwoman — who will Donald Trump pick from his long shortlist of running mates? And will his pick be based on strategy or aesthetics?

title.children: 'Out of central casting': Could Donald Trump choose this woman as running mate?

image.altText: bushfire at night

props.synopsis: Fire crews are battling a major blaze which has burnt through the night in southern Western Australia.

title.children: 'Out of control and unpredictable' bushfire burning in Western Australia

image.altText: Viona Agung is standing in front of a cafe, holding her smartphone up to capture a QR code displayed on the front counter.

props.synopsis: Viona is a cashback app user who has earned hundreds of dollars in cashback, but consumer advocacy group CHOICE is warning of privacy and personal data collection concerns.

title.children: Cashback apps boast millions of Australian users. But what price are you willing to pay for 'free' money?

image.altText: Two women crouch down to light candles in a crowd of people at a vigil

props.synopsis: A branch of Islamic State, the militant group that once sought control over swathes of Iraq and Syria, has claimed responsibility for a deadly terrorist attack at a Moscow concert hall. Here's what we know about ISIS-K.

title.children: Why is Islamic State 'fixated' on Russia?

image.altText: Workers in uniform stand inside a hall that has been destroyed by fire.

props.synopsis: Russia has not made public any evidence of a Ukrainian connection, and ISIS-K, a branch of the Islamic State group, has claimed responsibility for the attack.

title.children: Putin hints at Ukrainian involvement in Moscow concert hall attack as Russia arrests alleged gunmen

image.altText: King Tupou VI wearing a cloak walks into a building while a man sits down in the foreground and an attendant walks behind.

props.synopsis: The eyes of the Tongan public will this week settle on a remote island in the Pacific nation's north, where a meeting of the king with his advisers could determine the government's future.

title.children: Tonga's king will make the next move in his stand-off with the government — and the nation is watching

image.altText: Torrie Lewis

props.synopsis: Australian teenager Torrie Lewis anchors her relay team to victory in the 4x100m at the Sydney Track Classic, breaking a longstanding record along the way.

title.children: Teen sprint sensation Torrie Lewis helps Aussie relay team break 24-year-old record

image.altText: Sam Draper

props.synopsis: A Bombers star faces scrutiny after a high bump sparked an early brawl with the Swans, while earlier Melbourne's win was soured by injuries to two key players.

title.children: Swans win in spiteful match as Bombers star faces weeks on the sidelines for head high hit

image.altText: Two ladies wearing feathered and formal attire sit in a dimly lit room.

props.synopsis: For decades, women's only spaces have faced repeated challenges from men who say their missing out amounts to sex discrimination. So in 2024, is there still room for women-only — or men-only, for that matter — spaces?

title.children: No men allowed: The battle over women-only spaces continues

image.altText: Tasmanian Premier Jeremy Rockliff stands at the podium in the tally room in Hobart in front of his family

props.synopsis: Political parties that suffer a big drop in their vote and are on track to fall at short of a majority don't often claim victory, but that's exactly what Jeremy Rockliff did, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: The 'victory' speech despite no victory and other oddities of Tasmania's election night

image.altText: A large ship blasts a smaller boat with water in open ocean

props.synopsis: For the second time this month, the Chinese coastguard has fired a water cannon at a Philippine boat in the South China Sea, reportedly injuring some on board.

title.children: 'Irresponsible and provocative': Chinese coastguard hits Philippine boat with water cannon in South China Sea

image.altText: Composite of a young man wearing a windcheater and sunglasses, and an older man wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: Former real estate agent Zisi Kokotatsios, 63, faced Parramatta Bail Court after he was charged over the death of Mitch East last Sunday morning.

title.children: Sydney lawyer was lying on the road before he was allegedly run over by rideshare driver, court told

image.altText: Three police officers on horseback on Spring Street in central Melbourne

props.synopsis: Two women in their 20s have been arrested in Melbourne's CBD, as police defend their use of pepper spray against 'violent' protesters.

title.children: Police defend use of pepper spray outside Victorian Parliament House as protest turns violent

image.altText: A man stands at a podium with microphones in front of him.

props.synopsis: United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres says it is time for Israel to provide an "ironclad commitment" to unfettered access to humanitarian goods throughout Gaza, as fighting rages on around the strip's main hospital.

title.children: Visiting Rafah's border, UN secretary-general calls blocked aid for Gaza a 'moral outrage'

image.altText: A drone shot shows five vehicles involved in a highway crash.

props.synopsis: Police are investigating a multi-vehicle crash on the Bruce Highway that killed three people.

title.children: Three dead, three 'lucky to be alive' after Maryborough crash

image.altText: a forensic officer wearing a hazmat suit takes pictures at a mount druitt home after an alleged murder

props.synopsis: A man dies after being found in Melonba with significant injuries to his head and body.

title.children: Man charged with murder after alleged 'pre-arranged fight' in north-west Sydney

image.altText: A woman at a press conference

props.synopsis: The Real Estate Institute of Queensland says a focus on greater rights for tenants is diminishing the authority of property owners and overriding contractual freedoms.

title.children: Rent bidding shutdown, increase restrictions will harm landlord confidence, real estate lobby says

image.altText: Former cricketer Johan Botha stands with a wooden spoon with the letters 'DNF' written on it.

props.synopsis: As former South African international Johan Botha's cricketing career was winding down, he was bitten by the ultramarathon bug. Now he's targeting some of the world's longest runs.

title.children: 'You definitely need an understanding wife': How an international cricketer conquered ultramarathons
